section.name: 5 Minute Tutorial
section.p: If you have not read the 1 minute tutorial please start there.

subsection.name: Create initial configuration
subsection.p: Now you want to know how to read and create the initial root configuration. This part is a little tricky but please note that you only have to do it once. First of all you need to get an accessor for the configuration. Here is an example how to get access to a simple file.
subsection.source: File configFile = new File("myConfig.xml"); ConfigurationAccessIF accessor = new FileAccess(configFile);
subsection.p: Now you have to create a document using a factory for the proper format of the configuration. As we can guess from the filename the format will be XML in our example. So we use the following code:

Puh! That was the heavy part. Anyways this allows you to access your configuration from anywhere (file, URL, database, etc.) and in any format (XML, properties, etc.). Next we will see why we only need to create the initial configuration once.

subsection.name: Include configurations
subsection.p: The idea of this configuration library is that you can have a single configuration tree for complex and heterogenous configuration data. This does NOT mean that you should dump everything in one big file or all of your configuration is read into memory.
subsection.source: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <myRoot xmlns:cfg="http://m-m-m.sf.net/namespaces/configuration"> ... <myChild> <cfg:include access="file" type="xml" href="mySubConfiguration.xml" descendants="."/> </myChild> ... </myRoot>
subsection.p:
The <cfg:include> element in the XML above will automatically be replaced with the configuration from the XML file mySubConfiguration.xml.
The optional attributes access and type indicate the accessor(-factory) and the format. The required attribute href defines the location of the configuration and is interpreted by the accessor(-factory). For the accessor file you can also use glob-patterns in the path (e.g. plugins/*/configuration.xml). In this case all matching files are included at this point. Finally the optional descendants can be used if you do not want to include the complete configuration document (root-node(s)) but only parts of it. Therefore this attribute can be set to the path identifying the nodes (configuration descendants) to include.
